metadata.ttm:title: System Validations
metadata.ttm:desc: The eOffer/eMod system affords individuals whose Digital Certificate information no longer matches their business or personal information the opportunity to validate their credentials and submit requests of reinstatement to Contracting Officers. Whereas the process of reinstating oneself as an Authorized Negotiator once required the help of another Authorized Negotiator assigned to the same eOffer, or the outside help of a Contracting Officer, eOffer/eMod now facilitates interaction with the CO directly. This video explains the process.

div.p: In this video, we will discuss the mechanism GSA
has introduced that helps contractors when their
digital certificate information does not align
with the information associated with their
authorized negotiator in eOffer/eMods.
You will notice that, prior to accessing the
system, we have to confirm our identity through our
digital certificate.
For more general information on digital
certs, you should watch our series of training
videos posted to the eOffer/eMods home page.
At a high-level, the purpose of a digital
certificate is to assert your identity and assure
that eOffer/eMod verifies your authorization to
access the system and prepare or submit
documents.
In order to successfully access the system, your
digital certificate information must be an
exact match to that which is on your authorized
negotiator.
But what happens when it is not?
In the past, you would have needed to have a
different Authorized Negotiator log in to the
system and edit your details.
Or, if there was not another Authorized
Negotiator available to make the change, you would
need to contact your Contracting Officer and
ask him or her to manually enter the system and
change your details.
Not anymore.
GSA has made it easy for you to add yourself as a
negotiator to a contract or to modify your
negotiator information to align it with your digital
certificate.
Let's see how this process works.
Begin by selecting "Sign In" under Contract
Modifications.
As before, your digital certificate will appear.
Click OK to proceed through the system as
before.
Behind the scenes, a series of validations are
being run to ensure that the information on your
digital certificate matches that which is
associated with one of the Authorized Negotiators on
your contract.
The system is essentially trying to match the first
name, last name, or e-mail address on your digital
certificate to the first name, last name, and
e-mail address for each of your Authorized
Negotiators.
Let's first examine what happens if no match is
found.
The most likely reason for this scenario is that you
are trying to add yourself as an authorized
negotiator to the contract.
In this instance, you will need to provide your Name,
Title, Phone number, and e-mail address exactly as
it appears on your digital certificate.
Identify whether you are or are not Authorized to
Sign and click "Submit Request."
If there is another Authorized Negotiators on
the contract, the system will create a modification
pre-populated with the information you have
provided in order to add you as a new negotiator.
The existing Authorized Negotiator will receive an
e-mail notifying them that the modification has been
created and will now need to be submitted by them.
If no Authorized Negotiators are on the
contract, an e-mail will be sent requesting
approval from the Contracting Officer to add
you as a negotiator to the contract.
So what happens if some of the details on your
digital certificate match what is present for one or
more of the Authorized Negotiators on the
contract?
When entering your authorized negotiator
information, you may have neglected to add a middle
initial or used the wrong e-mail address.
You may have gotten married since you last
accessed the system and changed your name.
Any of these reasons could cause a problem during the
validation process.
So let's log in as we did before, selecting our
digital certificate.
This time, we can see that, while "Paul Tran" is
not a negotiator on the contract, "Paul Ran" is.
We can also see that a Paul.Tran@example.com is
tied to this account.
It is immediately apparent that, when entering Paul's
name as an Authorized Negotiator, someone
neglected to include the "T" in "Tran."
All we need to do now is select the radio button
next to "Paul Ran" and click "Initiate Request."
If there are no other Authorized Negotiators on
the contract, an e-mail will be sent to the
Contracting Officer assigned to the contract
who will then log in to the system and Accept or
Reject "Paul Tran's" inclusion as a negotiator
on the contract.
If there IS an Authorized Negotiator on the
contract, an e-mail will be sent instructing him or
her to submit a modification updating
Paul's name to match that which is on his digital
certificate.
If the authorized negotiator does not
respond to this e-mail within seven days, the
system will automatically notify the Contracting
Officer to initiate a modification to update the
Authorized Negotiator information.
We hope this information has proven useful to you.
Please check out our other training videos located
throughout the eOffer/eMod system as well as our
features on Digital Certificates and the
Importance of Authorized Negotiators.
Thank you for your continued support of GSA.
